metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Respondents (Trustees of Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple and Deputy Commissioner, HRCE)

facts.text: Agricultural lands in Eragudi village, Musiri taluk, Tiruchirappalli district granted in Inam to ancestor of Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar by Carnatic Rulers before British advent, burdened with obligation of performing services in a Matam.
Inam title deeds issued in favour of family of Pachai Kandai Udayavar in the sixties of the last century during Inam settlement.
Properties alienated from time to time; as result of last alienation, appellants became entitled to them.

Respondents 1 to 3 appointed trustees of alleged Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple at Eragudi by Respondent No. 4 (Deputy Commissioner, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments, Tiruchirappalli) on 7th March 1951.

Respondents 1 to 3 obtained certificate from Respondent 4 that properties belonged to Temple; filed application before Magistrate under S.87 Madras HRCE Act 1951 for possession; Magistrate overruled appellants' title claim and directed delivery of possession to Respondents 1 to 3.

Appellants instituted suit No. 103 of 1954 on 13th September 1954 in District Munsif at Turaiyur under S.87 Madras HRCE Act 1951 for declaration of title and permanent injunction restraining Respondents 1 to 3 from interfering with possession.
Respondents 1 to 3 contended properties granted to Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple and formed part of its properties.

Trial court framed issues: (1) whether grant was personal Inam; (2) whether religious endowment; (3) plaintiffs' title; (4) title by prescription. Held grant personal Inam, not religious endowment; appellants proved title and prescription. Decreed suit on 14th February 1955.

Respondents 1 to 3 appealed (No. 129 of 1955) to Subordinate Judge, Tiruchirappalli. Lower appellate court held no proof of temple existence; appellants acquired prescriptive title as alienations repudiation of trust. Dismissed appeal with costs on 29th March 1957.

Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 774 of 1957 (Subrahmanyam, J.): Grant to Temple; resumption by Collector only of melwaram; reversed no temple finding. On limitation under Art. 134-B Limitation Act: some alienations pre-1929 or auction sales outside Art. 134-B; Exts. A-3 (7.10.1917), A-6 (2.7.1926), A-12 (2.7.1926) within Art. 134-B. Partly allowed appeal, set aside decree re those on 2nd September 1959.

Alienor Pachaikandaswamiar and son left village >25 years before suit; sold all properties; no interest in temple; Raju Iyer and Amirthalinga Iyer performed worship for 27 years; notice 19.6.1948 by Asst. Commissioner stated no legally constituted trustees, mismanaged, proposed appointment; described others as de facto trustees.
Specific alienations: Ext. A-2 (1914) items 1,2,pt3,7,8,pt well item5; Exts A-7,A-8 (1927 auction) item4, pt item6; Exts A-3,A-6,A-12 (1917,1926,1926).

legal_issues.text: Whether the original grant was a personal Inam to Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar or to the Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple as religious endowment.
Whether appellants acquired title by prescription/adverse possession.

Whether Art. 134-B Limitation Act applies to alienations where alienors transferred properties as their own separate secular properties (not as managers), or only if transferred as endowment property; if Art. 144 applies instead.
If Art. 134-B applies, whether limitation period started from removal/resignation of transferor Pachaikandaswamiar more than 12 years before suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Grant was personal Inam burdened with service to Matam, not to religious endowment; appellants have title; acquired by prescription.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 S.87

petitioner_arguments.text: Art. 134-B does not apply as alienors transferred as owners of separate secular properties (recitals in deeds), not as poojaris/managers; void ab initio, adverse possession from transfer date under Art. 144.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Limitation Act Arts. 134-B, 144; Gnanasambanda Pandara Sannadhi v. Velu Pandaram; Damodar Das v. Adhikari Lakham Das; B.K. Mukherjea on Hindu Law of Religious and Charitable Trust

petitioner_arguments.text: Even under Art. 134-B, Pachaikandaswamiar resigned/removed >27/25 years ago; de facto managers took over; limitation from then.

respondent_arguments.text: Properties granted to Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple; belong to it; respondents 1-3 trustees entitled to possession.
No temple existence not proved (High Court reversed); alienations unauthorised; Art. 134-B applies, title not perfected.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 134-B applies regardless of whether previous manager represented property as endowment's or his own; successor must prove property in endowment, transferred by previous manager for value; character of representations irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plain words of Art. 134-B cover all such transfers; no distinction based on basis of transfer.

court_reasoning.text: History of law post-Vidya Varuthi led to Art. 134-B; earlier cases like Gnanasambanda/Damodar Das distinguished as involved office transfer or pre-Vidya position.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No authority supports exception for transfers as 'own property'; would undermine Art. 134-B.

court_reasoning.text: Facts show alienor Pachaikandaswamiar removed from management >25 years ago; sold all properties, left village; others acted as de facto managers; limitation under Art. 134-B runs from removal, >12 years before suit/appointment of R1-3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence of de facto management takeover proves removal.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in not considering removal; trial/lower appellate courts right on prescription.

holdings.text: Art. 134-B Limitation Act applies to transfers by previous manager of Hindu endowment for value, irrespective of whether transferor claimed it as endowment property or own private property.
Under Art. 134-B, limitation runs from death/resignation/removal of transferor; here, removal >12 years before suit, so appellants' title perfected.
Appellants entitled to decree in entirety; properties not temple's due to limitation.
Suit not barred; appellants have title.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha v. Balusami Ayyar
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager of math not trustee; led to insertion of Arts. 134A/B/C.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gnanasambanda Pandara Sannadhi v. Velu Pandaram
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale of office and properties; adverse possession from start under Art. 124/144.

precedents_cited.case_name: Damodar Das v. Adhikari Lakham Das
Mahant Ram Charan Das v. Naurangi Lal
Mahadeo Prasad Singh v. Karia Bharti
Mahant Sudarsan Das v. Mahant Ram Kirpal Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 134-B does not cover execution sales.
Shebait alienation not binding on successors.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hemanta Kumari Basu v. Sree Ishwar Sridhar Jiu
precedents_cited.relevance: Mukherjea J. view on transfers as own property.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Suit filed under; application for possession by trustees.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs limitation for recovering possession of transferred endowment property; starts from death/resignation/removal of transferor.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appellants' appeal by special leave, set aside Madras High Court decree insofar as it rejected claim re Exts. A-3, A-6, A-12, restored lower appellate court decree decreeing suit in entirety in favour of appellants.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of title and permanent injunction in favour of appellants for all suit properties.
outcome.costs: Not specified; lower appellate court had costs on respondents.

key_quotes.text: Article 134-B applies to all cases where it is shown that the immovable property was comprised in the endowment and that it has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding rejecting distinction based on transfer representation.

key_quotes.text: All the facts... clearly show not only that the alienor disposed of all the property and left the village but also that for the last 25 years or so, the management has been taken over by other persons who are acting as de facto managers of the temple.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for finding removal triggering limitation.
